executive_summary: Tiny Whirlwinds has a validated product that parents love, a genuine structural advantage (Farnham's only dedicated sensory studio), and a founder who nails the delivery — but right now, almost nobody knows it exists. The entire game for the next 90 days is visibility: getting Farnham parents through the door, because the class sells itself once they're in the room. This is a CONDITIONAL GO — the product works, the market's there, but marketing execution is the make-or-break.

reality_check: 4 term bookings is a start, not traction. You need 8-10 per class to feel viable and 12+ to feel healthy.
Instagram is 2 days old with 90 followers and 1 post. For a B2C baby business, this is effectively zero social presence.
No Google My Business profile, no Happity listing, no local partnerships. You're invisible to parents actively searching.
Only 2 of 4 class types running (Stargazers 0-6mo, Explorers 6-15mo). Active Adventurers unmapped, Parties not ready but still on website.
Solo operator with no backup plan. One illness away from cancelled classes.
Revenue: pre-revenue. Unit economics unknown — breakeven fill rate not calculated.
Website is clean but generic — doesn't communicate the GENTLE positioning or studio advantage.
what_is_working: The class itself. Trial classes with 6-10 attendees got great feedback. Babies stayed engaged. Jade was confident by session 4.
The studio. A dedicated sensory space with light shows, tactile stations, and proper production values. No local competitor has this.
The positioning. Gentle sensory fills a real gap — parents find Hartbeeps 'too in your face' and Baby Sensory overcrowded.
The pricing. £10/class (term) is competitive with franchises but delivers a premium experience. No franchise fees eating margins.
The founder. Tech background (Dexla), genuinely passionate, IS her own ICP — a Farnham mum who built what she couldn't find.
current_stage_diagnosis.honest_assessment: You've done the hardest part — building something genuinely good. Most people never get here. But a great product that nobody knows about is a failed business. The next 30 days will determine whether Tiny Whirlwinds becomes a thriving local institution or a well-kept secret.

the_one_thing.focus: Get 20 new parents into your studio in the next 30 days.
the_one_thing.why: Everything else flows from this. Bookings create revenue. Revenue creates sustainability. Full classes create word-of-mouth. Word-of-mouth creates more bookings. But the flywheel can't spin without those first parents in the room. Your class sells itself — the job is getting people through the door.
the_one_thing.how: Three actions, in order of impact: (1) Visit 5 local venues this week with leaflets — health centre, children's centre, NCT coffee morning, two cafés with parent corners. Introduce yourself in person. (2) Message your 4 existing parents today with a 'bring a friend free' offer for launch week. (3) Post on Instagram 4x this week — launch reel, studio setup, behind-the-scenes, and a 'tips for parents' carousel. That's it. No fancy marketing strategy needed. Just those three things.
the_one_thing.what_to_ignore_for_now: Franchise planning. Brand guidelines. Active Adventurers curriculum. TikTok. A perfect website. Parties offering. Weekend classes. All good ideas — all distractions from the one thing that matters right now.

strategic_thesis.the_bet: The bet is that an independent, studio-based, gentle-sensory baby class can out-compete national franchises in a local market by being genuinely better where it matters: smaller groups, better environment, more personal, more authentic.
why_it_can_work: Demand is proven. Baby Sensory is always full in Farnham — there are more parents wanting classes than current supply serves.
The #1 parent complaint (overcrowding) is structurally solved by having a dedicated studio with controlled capacity.
Hartbeeps appears to have exited Farnham — that's a gap in the market with displaced parents.
Parent forums consistently say the individual class leader matters more than the brand. Jade's warmth and delivery quality can beat any franchise script.
Farnham is affluent Surrey — parents here spend on premium baby experiences and the £10/class price point is comfortable.
Post-COVID demand for in-person baby activities exceeds pre-COVID levels. Timing is strong.
Jade's tech background is a dormant superpower — when activated, it creates operational advantages no local competitor can match.
strategic_thesis.the_risk_in_the_bet: The bet fails if Jade can't solve the marketing problem. The product is invisible right now. If classes don't fill within 6 weeks of launch, the studio rent burns cash with no revenue to offset it. The bet also fails if solo-operator burnout hits before the business reaches sustainability.
strategic_thesis.what_makes_this_different_from_yet_anoth: Three things no franchise in Farnham can replicate: (1) a purpose-built sensory studio with professional production values, (2) an indie founder story that parents connect with emotionally, and (3) a tech-savvy operator who can out-systemise competitors who run on WhatsApp groups and bank transfers.

instagram.current_state: 90 followers, 1 post, 2 days old. Effectively starting from zero.
instagram.why_it_matters: Instagram is THE discovery channel for baby classes. Farnham mums scroll Instagram during 2am feeds and nap-trapped afternoons. Your light shows, sensory setups, and baby reactions are inherently visual and shareable. One good Reel can reach thousands of local parents.

30_day_plan.posting_cadence: 4x per week minimum: 2 Reels, 1 carousel, 1 Story sequence
content_pillars: Studio magic — Reels of light shows turning on, room transformations, setup timelapses
Baby reactions — short clips (with permission) of babies engaging with sensory stations
Jade's story — why you started, what you were looking for, honest founder moments
Value content — 'Easy sensory play at home' carousels that help parents even if they never book
Social proof — parent quotes overlaid on class footage, milestone moments
tactical_tips: Batch film on class days — 1 hour of filming = 2 weeks of content
Hook in first 1.5 seconds (lights turning on, a baby's face, a surprising texture)
Engage 15 mins/day — follow and genuinely comment on local mum accounts
Stories for daily behind-the-scenes; Reels for reach; carousels for value
Pin your launch Reel and a 'What to expect at your first class' post to your profile
30_day_plan.realistic_target: 300+ followers in 30 days, 10+ DM enquiries, 3+ bookings traceable to Instagram
30_day_plan.mindset_shift: You're not 'doing marketing'. You're helping Farnham mums find something brilliant you made for them. Every post you don't share is a mum who doesn't know you exist.

local_partnerships.current_state: Zero partnerships. Acknowledged as a good idea but not started.
local_partnerships.why_it_matters: This is your fastest path to full classes. One health visitor recommendation is worth 100 Instagram followers. These professionals interact with every new parent in your area and are actively looking for good activities to recommend.

priority_targets.venue: Farnham health centre / health visitor clinics
priority_targets.approach: Visit in person with leaflets. Introduce yourself as a local mum running sensory classes. Ask to leave leaflets and if they'd be willing to mention you to new parents.
priority_targets.impact: Very high — health visitors see EVERY new parent

priority_targets.approach: Offer a free 15-min sensory taster at their next coffee morning. Bring a portable kit (UV light, textures, bubbles).
priority_targets.impact: High — concentrated group of your exact ICP

priority_targets.approach: Leave leaflets, ask about noticeboard space, offer to run a free taster session.

priority_targets.venue: Local cafés with parent corners (e.g., Farnham café culture)
priority_targets.approach: Leave cards/leaflets at the till. Offer a referral arrangement — their customers get a trial discount.
priority_targets.impact: Medium — passive discovery but builds local presence

priority_targets.approach: Attend, be friendly, mention your classes naturally when relevant.

local_partnerships.this_week_action: Visit 3 venues before launch. That's it. Introduce yourself, leave leaflets, be genuine. This single action will do more than any amount of Instagram strategy.

google_presence.current_state: No Google My Business profile detected. Likely invisible in 'baby classes Farnham' searches.
google_presence.why_it_matters: Parents Google 'baby classes near me' and 'sensory classes Farnham'. Without a Google Business Profile, you don't exist in these searches. This is free, takes 2 hours to set up, and works 24/7.
setup_checklist: Create Google Business Profile at business.google.com
Upload 10+ photos of the studio, classes, Jade teaching
Write a description emphasising: Farnham, dedicated studio, gentle sensory, small groups
Add booking link, class times, contact details
Verify the business (postcard or phone verification)
After each class, ask happy parents for a Google review — send them the direct review link
Post weekly updates (Google Posts) with class photos and term availability
google_presence.target: Profile live before launch. 5+ reviews within first term. Appearing in Maps results for key searches within 2 weeks.
google_presence.also_do: List on Happity (2.6M parents/year — the Rightmove of baby classes), Netmums local, and any other free directories. Takes 1 hour total.

competitive_positioning.summary: Farnham has 3-4 direct competitors (Lullababy, Tots Play, Baby Sensory area franchise, Jo Jingles) plus free alternatives. Most are franchises operating from hired community halls. Tiny Whirlwinds occupies genuinely distinct territory.

gentle_vs_high_energy.tiny_whirlwinds: Gentle, calm, wonder-led. Babies aren't overwhelmed — just wonderfully engaged.
gentle_vs_high_energy.hartbeeps: High-energy, theatrical, character-driven. Some parents love it; others find it 'too in your face' for babies.
gentle_vs_high_energy.baby_sensory: Middle ground but tends towards overstimulation in overcrowded sessions.
gentle_vs_high_energy.lullababy: Gentle (yoga-adjacent) but lacks the production values and wonder element.
gentle_vs_high_energy.your_lane: You own 'gentle but magical'. Calm environment, professional production (light shows, sound), intimate groups. The parents who find Hartbeeps too much and Baby Sensory too crowded? They're yours.

indie_vs_franchise.franchise_advantages: Brand recognition (parents Google 'Baby Sensory' by name), proven lesson plans, national marketing, established trust
indie_vs_franchise.indie_advantages: No franchise fees (£6-25k saved), no royalties (10-15% of revenue), full creative control, authentic founder story, agility to adapt
indie_vs_franchise.your_play: Lead with the founder story — 'I'm Jade, a Farnham mum who built this because I couldn't find what I wanted for my baby.' Parents connect with real people, not logos. Your authenticity is unchallengeable. Franchisees read scripts; you wrote yours.

studio_vs_hired_hall.studio_advantages: Consistent environment every session, professional setup (not assembling in a cold church hall 30 mins before class), controlled lighting and sound, always-ready sensory stations, clean and purpose-designed, premium feel
studio_vs_hired_hall.hall_disadvantages: Variable quality, setup/teardown time, shared with other groups, no control over temperature/lighting, 'making do' rather than purpose-built
studio_vs_hired_hall.your_advantage: This is your biggest structural differentiator. When a parent walks into your studio and compares it to a church hall with portable speakers, the choice makes itself. SHOW this advantage — on Instagram, on your website, in Google photos. Let the space do the selling.

competitive_positioning.competitive_message: You don't need to attack competitors. Just state your truth clearly: 'Farnham's only dedicated baby sensory studio. Small groups. Gentle approach. A space designed entirely for your baby's wonder.' Parents will draw their own comparisons.

metrics_to_track.note: These are local service business metrics, not SaaS metrics. No MRR, no CAC/LTV ratios, no cohort analysis needed yet. Keep it simple.

weekly_metrics.target: 8+ per class (first term), 10-12 per class (by term 2)
weekly_metrics.how: Count bums on mats. Track per class type and time slot.
weekly_metrics.why: This is THE metric. Everything else follows from full classes.

weekly_metrics.target: 5+ per week once marketing is active
weekly_metrics.how: Count DMs, emails, phone calls, booking page visits

weekly_metrics.target: Know where every parent heard about you
weekly_metrics.how: Add 'How did you hear about us?' to booking flow. Ask at first class.
weekly_metrics.why: Tells you which channels to double down on and which to drop.

term_metrics.target: 40%+ (i.e., 4 in 10 trial parents book a term)
term_metrics.how: Track: tried a class → booked a term
term_metrics.why: If this is low, the class isn't converting — investigate why.
Retention proves the product creates lasting value. Cheaper than acquiring new parents.

term_metrics.target: Breakeven by end of term 1, profitable by term 2
term_metrics.how: Simple spreadsheet: class revenue minus studio rent, equipment, insurance, platform fees, consumables
term_metrics.why: You need to know your breakeven fill rate. How many classes at what capacity covers your fixed costs?

term_metrics.target: 5+ reviews in first term, 15+ by end of year
term_metrics.how: Ask happy parents after class. Send direct review link.
term_metrics.why: Reviews are permanent social proof that drive organic discovery.

quarterly_metrics.target: Any waitlist is a great sign
quarterly_metrics.how: Track when classes are full and how many are waiting
quarterly_metrics.why: Waitlists signal demand for expansion — more time slots, new class types, eventually new locations.

quarterly_metrics.target: 500 by end of Q1, 1000 by end of Q2
quarterly_metrics.why: Proxy for brand awareness in your local market. Quality of engagement matters more than raw numbers.

quarterly_metrics.how: Launch when existing classes are consistently 80%+ full
quarterly_metrics.why: More class types = more age coverage = longer customer lifetime = more revenue.

risks_and_mitigations.impact: Cancelled classes, refunds, reputation damage, potential business failure
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Identify and train a backup class leader within 3 months. Even a friend who can run a simplified 'class in a box' at 70% quality. Budget £50-100/session for cover. Also: set boundaries — take weekends off, don't run classes when genuinely sick, build recovery time into the schedule.

risks_and_mitigations.impact: Studio rent burns cash with no offsetting revenue. Business isn't viable.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Execute the P0 marketing experiments (leaflet drops, Google My Business, Instagram sprint, bring-a-friend offer) BEFORE launch. If classes aren't at 8+ attendees after 6 weeks of active marketing, reassess: is it pricing? Timing? Location? Awareness? Don't just keep doing the same thing harder.

risks_and_mitigations.impact: The marketing gap never closes. The business stays invisible.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Simplify ruthlessly. Not 8 channels — just 3: leaflet drops + Instagram + Google. Not perfection — just consistency. 15 minutes a day on Instagram. One local venue visit per week. That's enough. Consider a part-time social media helper (local uni student, £10-12/hr, 3-5 hrs/week) if it stays overwhelming after 30 days.

risks_and_mitigations.impact: Increased competition for a small market. Brand recognition advantage for the franchise.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: First-mover advantage in the 'dedicated studio' niche. Build community loyalty now — parents who love you won't switch. Accumulate Google reviews and Instagram presence as a defensive moat. Your studio is structurally unreplicable by a franchise operating from hired halls.

risks_and_mitigations.impact: Parents see 'Parties' and 'Active Adventurers' as available, get confused when they can't book. '100+ babies' claim may not be accurate.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: This week: remove Parties page, mark Active Adventurers as 'Coming Soon — join waitlist', verify or remove the 100+ babies claim. Takes 1-2 hours with Jade's tech skills.

risks_and_mitigations.impact: July-August is the low season for baby classes. Fixed costs (studio rent) continue.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Plan ahead: summer holiday specials, outdoor pop-up sessions, birthday party offering (once ready). Build a cash buffer during term time. This isn't urgent now but needs planning by May.

risks_and_mitigations.risk: Falling UK birth rate shrinks addressable market
risks_and_mitigations.impact: Long-term: fewer babies means more competition for each one.
risks_and_mitigations.mitigation: Farnham is affluent — spend-per-child is increasing even as births decline. Focus on premium positioning and high retention. This is a 5-10 year headwind, not an immediate crisis.

must_do: Visit 5 local venues with leaflets (health centre, children's centre, NCT, 2 cafés)
Set up Google My Business profile with photos and complete information
List on Happity and other free discovery platforms
Post on Instagram 4x/week for 30 days (2 Reels, 1 carousel, 1 Story sequence)
Send 'bring a friend free' offer to all 4 existing term parents
Clean up website: remove Parties, fix Active Adventurers, add Jade's story, add 'Farnham' to titles
Add 'How did you hear about us?' to booking flow
LAUNCH the classes and deliver brilliantly
days_0_to_30.success_looks_like: 8+ parents per class by week 4. 300+ Instagram followers. Google profile live with 2+ reviews. 3+ local venues have your leaflets.

must_do: Join and become active in 3+ local Facebook parent groups
Host a free taster session at an NCT coffee morning or children's centre
Ask every happy parent for a Google review (target: 5+ reviews)
Start collecting video testimonials (even just phone clips of parents saying something nice)
Calculate actual breakeven fill rate — know your numbers
Continue Instagram at 4x/week, start tracking what content performs best
Begin relationship with at least 1 health visitor who recommends you
days_30_to_60.success_looks_like: Classes consistently at 8-10 attendees. Trial-to-term conversion rate above 40%. 2+ bookings from local partnerships. Clear understanding of unit economics.

must_do: If classes are 80%+ full: add a new time slot or open Active Adventurers waitlist
Identify and begin training a backup class leader
Build a simple parent CRM (even a Google Sheet): name, baby name/age, first class date, source, rebooking status
Plan for Term 2: set dates, open bookings, email existing parents first (retention advantage)
Test one Saturday morning class if demand signals are there
Review what marketing channels are actually driving bookings — double down on winners, drop losers
Set up automated booking confirmation and review request emails if not already done
days_60_to_90.success_looks_like: 60%+ term rebooking rate. Waitlist forming for at least one class. Backup teacher identified. Clear picture of which channels drive bookings. Revenue covering costs or close to it.
days_60_to_90.budget: ~£100-200 (backup teacher training sessions, any paid tools)

franchise_honest_assessment.the_dream: A multi-town franchise network of dedicated sensory studios. Tiny Whirlwinds as a recognised brand with franchisees across Surrey, Hampshire, and beyond. Franchise fee income plus royalties creating a scalable business beyond Jade's personal class delivery.
franchise_honest_assessment.is_it_realistic: Yes — eventually. The concept is genuinely differentiated from existing baby class franchises. A dedicated-studio model with controlled class sizes and premium positioning IS a franchise-worthy proposition. The market supports it: franchise fees of £10-15k with lower royalties than Baby Sensory (£15-25k) could be very attractive to aspiring baby class operators.
franchise_honest_assessment.when_to_think_about_it: Not now. Not for at least 12-18 months. Here's the honest timeline:

franchise_readiness_timeline.criteria: 3+ class types running, consistently 80%+ full, 60%+ rebooking, profitable, 50+ Google reviews, strong Instagram presence, word-of-mouth generating organic enquiries
franchise_readiness_timeline.what_to_do: Document everything: session plans, setup procedures, marketing playbook, financial model, what worked and what didn't. This is your franchise operations manual being written in real time.

franchise_readiness_timeline.criteria: Backup teacher successfully running classes. Booking, marketing, and admin systems are repeatable and documentable. Brand guidelines exist. Training process defined.
franchise_readiness_timeline.what_to_do: Test the model with a second location (still you/your team, not a franchisee). Maybe Aldershot or Guildford. Prove it works outside Farnham.

franchise_readiness_timeline.criteria: 2 locations running profitably. Complete operations manual. Training programme. Legal framework (franchise agreement). Marketing support system. At least one person who isn't Jade successfully running a TW location.
franchise_readiness_timeline.what_to_do: Get proper franchise legal advice (BFA members). Build the franchise offering. Start with 1-2 carefully selected franchisees. Grow slowly — franchise reputation is everything.

franchise_honest_assessment.the_trap_to_avoid: Thinking about franchise-stage problems (brand guidelines, territory maps, licensing models) while you have 4 bookings. Write your franchise ideas in a 'Future' doc, close it, and don't open it for 6 months. Every ounce of energy spent on franchise thinking is an ounce not spent on filling Farnham classes. The franchise dream DEPENDS on Farnham being a screaming success. That's where 100% of your focus belongs.
franchise_honest_assessment.the_encouragement: Your tech background gives you a massive advantage here. Most baby class founders couldn't build a franchise operations system if they tried. You can. You'll build better booking systems, better training tools, better marketing templates than Baby Sensory's 20-year-old franchise pack. But first — prove it in the room.

closing_note: Jade — you've built something genuinely special. A dedicated sensory studio, a curriculum that works, a gentle positioning that parents are asking for. You're not another franchise clone in a church hall. You're the real thing. The only thing standing between where you are and a full, thriving business is this: tell people about it. Walk into the health centre. Post the Reel. Message those parents. The product is ready. The market is ready. You just need to be visible. Everything starts there. Go fill those classes.
